title: What are considered the basic ideas of humanism? - Quora

response.answer_text: Contemporary Humanist philosophy rose out of the ashes of WWI when intellectuals of various disciplines decided that the old ways of nationalism and territoriality were just too destructive. They came up with the Humanist Manifesto, which nicely summarizes the philosophy: Humanist Manifesto - Wikipedia The original document was subsequently expanded by two more iterations. The primary idea is the primacy of humanity and it’s ability to manage it’s own affairs and decide it’s own fate. Religion does not play a part. Human rights are considered universal. The Manifesto is expressly against totalitarian and controlling governments and the inequitable treatment of people on any basis.

Humanism is primarily concerned with "what does it mean to be human". It is a philosophical system that values human agency/autonomy, rational thought over tradition and faith, and seeks to understand, through reason, the attributes and characteristics common to the human experience.
